citations.narrative:
Four enclosures housing 7, 5, 5, and 8 domestic kittens had electrical wires in the enclosures. Unprotected electrical
wires in enclosures pose a rick of shock, electrocution, and strangulation. The electrical wires need to be oriented in such
a way that the animals cannot interact with them.
Correct by October 24, 2023

An enclosure housing 4 red ruffed lemurs and 1 black-and-white ruffed lemur, an enclosure housing 4 common squirrel
monkeys, an enclosure housing 2 ring-tailed lemurs, and an enclosure housing 2 common brown lemurs had electrical
wires in the enclosures. Unprotected electrical wires in enclosures pose a rick of shock, electrocution, and strangulation.
The electrical wires need to be oriented in such a way that the animals cannot interact with them.
Correct by October 24, 2023

The licensee exhibits animals in a manner that does not pose minimal risk of harm to the animals and to the public, nor in
a way that the animals are under the direct control and supervision of an experienced handler or trainer at all times when
the public is present.
May 14 2023, a member of the public posted photos of a minor child holding a ring-tailed lemur at the licensee’s facility.
There was not an identifiable method of effective direct control by an experienced handler or established barrier in this
photo with the public member and the ring-tailed lemur.
May 14 2023, a member of the public posted photos of herself and a second adult on social media holding a ring-tailed
lemur at the licensee’s facility. There was not an identifiable method of effective direct control by an experienced handler
or established barrier in this photo with the public member or the ring-tailed lemur.
May 4 2023, a member of the public posted photos of herself on social media holding a ring-tailed lemur and a brown
capuchin and interacting with a red ruffed lemur at the licensee’s facility. There was not an identifiable method of effective
direct control by an experienced handler or established barrier in this photo with the public member and the red ruffed
lemur, the ring-tailed lemur, or the brown capuchin. The May 4 picture shows a lemur up by a patron’s head and face.
This increases the risk of harm, injury and/or zoonotic concerns to the public and animal.
USDA Officials showed the licensee an assortment of these social media photos and they confirmed that these were their
animals. During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so that there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to
the public with sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the
safety of animals and the public. The facility should ensure the well-being of both parties by not allowing members of the
public to handle animals without the facility maintaining direct control. When allowing members of the public to hold the
animal, then physical control is necessary to ensure the experienced handler maintains adequate direct control at all
times. Additionally, the facility’s volunteers and/or employees should be readily identifiable and have the appropriate
documentation showing their training/experience with handling animals.
Correct by December 19, 2023

An enclosure housing 1 bat-eared fox and 1 cape fox and an enclosure housing 1 prehensile-tailed porcupine had
electrical wires in the enclosures. Unprotected electrical wires in enclosures pose a rick of shock, electrocution, and
strangulation. The electrical wires need to be oriented in such a way that the animals cannot interact with them.
Correct by October 24, 2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.1(a) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
Four enclosures housing 7, 5, 5, and 8 domestic kittens had electrical wires in the enclosures. Unprotected electrical 
wires in enclosures pose a rick of shock, electrocution, and strangulation. The electrical wires need to be oriented in such

3.75(a) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
An enclosure housing 4 red ruffed lemurs and 1 black-and-white ruffed lemur, an enclosure housing 4 common squirrel 
monkeys, an enclosure housing 2 ring-tailed lemurs, and an enclosure housing 2 common brown lemurs had electrical

The electrical wires need to be oriented in such a way that the animals cannot interact with them.

3.78(e) 
   
Outdoor housing facilities. 
The licensee exhibits animals in a manner that does not pose minimal risk of harm to the animals and to the public, nor in 
a way that the animals are under the direct control and supervision of an experienced handler or trainer at all times when 
the public is present. 
May 14 2023, a member of the public posted photos of a minor child holding a ring-tailed lemur at the licensee’s facility.

May 4 2023, a member of the public posted photos of herself on social media holding a ring-tailed lemur and a brown

direct control by an experienced handler or established barrier in this photo with the public member and the red ruffed

This increases the risk of harm, injury and/or zoonotic concerns to the public and animal.  
 
USDA Officials showed the licensee an assortment of these social media photos and they confirmed that these were their

times. Additionally, the facility’s volunteers and/or employees should be readily identifiable and have the appropriate 
documentation showing their training/experience with handling animals. 
Correct by December 19, 2023 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
An enclosure housing 1 bat-eared fox and 1 cape fox and an enclosure housing 1 prehensile-tailed  porcupine had 
electrical wires in the enclosures. Unprotected electrical wires in enclosures pose a rick of shock, electrocution, and

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
